sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter demonstrates basic CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations using Reladomo.
Imagine that we want to build a REST API for our Petstore. The API for Person could look like this.
sect1.programlisting: GET /person Get all Persons GET /person/{id} Get a Person by id GET /person/{lastName} Get all Persons by last name. POST /person Create a Person with the POST payload PUT /person/{id} Update the details of a Person DELETE /person/{id} Delete a Person
sect1.para: To implement each of the above listed APIs, we need to use Reladomo to create, fetch and modify objects in the database.

sect1.title: Object Creation (C)
sect1.para: Creating objects is straightfoward in Reladomo. For each MithraObject, Reladmoo generates a no-arg constructor. Simply invoke the constructor and invoke the generated setter methods. These methods correspond to the attributes defined in the MithraObject XML. Then insert the object by invoking the generated insert method. sect1.note: The generated classes are meant to be modified. However, the default no-arg constructor has to be preserved as it is used internally by Reladomo. When adding a custom constructor make sure to call the no-arg constructor.

sect2.para: Consider the case where we want to create (insert) a PetType, Pet and Person. The naive approach is to instantiate and insert each object individually. Another option is to wire up the object graph and let Reladomo cascade the inserts.

sect1.title: Object Read (R)
sect1.para: Objects are read using generated classes called Finders. There are two parts to a finder. The first is the Operation. An operation corresponds to an expression in a SQL where clause. For each attribute in the MithraObject, Reladomo generates a method named after the attribute. These methods return Attribute objects which in turn expose methods that return Operations.
Operations can also be chained. Once an operation is built, one of the generated findMany, findOne methods is used to actually fetch the objects.

note.title: Caching
note.para: When a Finder is invoked, Reladomo normally constructs a SQL query and executes it against the database. However, this is not always the case. If the object has been cached in memory, Reladomo will return the cached object instead of hitting the database.

sect2.title: Cursors
sect2.para: When a finder that returns a list is invoked, the entire list is forced into memory. This is not ideal if the list is huge. Clearly this can be very inefficient for large lists. This problem is fixed by using a "deep fetch". When a deep fetch is performed, Reladomo will not only fetch the object in question, but will also traverse the relationship graph to fetch related objects. For each Relationship defined in the MithraObject, Reladomo generates a related finder instance which can be used to fetch related objects. In this case, the pets related finder is because of the pets relationship between Person and Pet.
sect2.programlisting: <Relationship name="pets" relatedObject="Pet" cardinality="one-to-many" relatedIsDependent="true" reverseRelationshipName="owner"> this.personId = Pet.personId </Relationship>
sect2.para: Now with the deep fetch configured, Reladomo issues a single query against the database.

sect1.title: Object Modification (U)
sect1.para: Objects retrieved via finders are "live" objects. Any changes made to these objects via the generated setters are reflected in the database immediately.
In the following snippet, execution of the setter in line 2 results in a SQL update statement being executed against the database.

In some cases this is not desirable. For example, you might want a set of updates to an object to be executed atomically. Or set a of updates to multiple objects be executed atomically. In these cases, the solution is to wrap the updates in a transaction.

sect2.title: Detached Objects
sect2.para: As described previously, an objected fetched via a Finder is a "live" object ; changes to which are immediately flushed to the database. To disable these flushes, simply detach the object from the database.

sect1.para: In the above snippet, the set of the first name in line 3 is flushed to the database right away. In line 5 the object is detached via the getDetachedCopy method. After it has been detached, the set of the first name in the subsequent line is not flushed to the database.
Detaching an object not only detaches that object, but the entire object graph attached to the object.
